001package org.consensusj.bitcoin.json.conversion;
002
003import com.fasterxml.jackson.core.JsonParser;
004import com.fasterxml.jackson.core.JsonProcessingException;
005import com.fasterxml.jackson.core.JsonToken;
006import com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.DeserializationContext;
007import com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.JsonDeserializer;
008import org.bitcoinj.base.Coin;
009
010import java.io.IOException;
011import java.math.BigDecimal;
012
013/**
014 * Deserialize a numeric value to a bitcoinj {@link Coin} type.
015 */
016public class CoinDeserializer extends JsonDeserializer<Coin> {
017    @Override
018    public Coin deserialize(JsonParser p, DeserializationContext ctxt) throws IOException, JsonProcessingException {
019        JsonToken token = p.getCurrentToken();
020        switch (token) {
021
022            case VALUE_NUMBER_FLOAT:
023                BigDecimal bd = p.getDecimalValue();
024                return Coin.ofBtc(bd);
025
026            case VALUE_NUMBER_INT:
027                // TODO: Is this really what we want here? To treat JSON floats as BTC values and JSON integers as Satoshis?
028                long val = p.getNumberValue().longValue(); // should be optimal, whatever it is
029                return Coin.ofSat(val);
030
031            // Read a numeric string. There are cases where a BTC decimal balance is encoded wrapped with quotes.
032            case VALUE_STRING:
033                return Coin.parseCoin(p.getText());
034
035            default:
036                return (Coin) ctxt.handleUnexpectedToken(Coin.class, p);
037        }
038    }
039}
